question.title: Unable to create new folder inside src/main/java in IntelliJ IDEA when folder is marked as Sources Root
question.body:
I’m working on a Java Spring Boot project in IntelliJ IDEA. My folder structure is like this: src/main/java/com/discordbot/sentry

The problem is:

  • The src/main/java folder is marked as Sources Root (blue folder).

  • Inside IntelliJ, the nested packages sometimes show as a single folder with dots (like com.discordbot.sentry).

  • I can’t create new directories inside src/main/java or inside these package folders unless I unmark the folder as Sources Root.

  • I want to add new regular folders (not Java packages) inside the source folder for resources or bot modules.

What am I missing? How can I create normal folders inside a Sources Root in IntelliJ IDEA without breaking the project structure?

Please bear with me as I’m still learning. I’m hoping someone can clarify the reasoning behind this behavior or suggest a better workflow.

Thanks in advance!

I have read the official JetBrains article explaining how to create regular directories inside a Java project in IntelliJ IDEA: https://youtrack.jetbrains.com/articles/SUPPORT-A-345/How-to-create-a-regular-directory-not-a-package-in-a-Java-project-in-IntelliJ-IDEA

The explanation is pretty clear and easy to understand. I followed the instructions about unmarking the folder as a Sources Root to create regular directories.

However, what I don’t understand is why IntelliJ enforces these restrictions at all — why can’t I create normal folders inside a Sources Root without unmarking it?

I’m hoping someone can clarify the reasoning behind this behavior or suggest a better workflow.

answers.body:
Why folders are changing into packages?

Java packages are folders actually. If you mark a directory of folder as sources root then folders inside (subdirectories) will be treated as packages until you explicitly mark them as excluded or resource in IntelliJ-IDEA.

How to create directory for resources?

You can mark any directory under Java project as resources and put resource files like images, audios or any non-code files inside them

File >> Project Structure >> Modules >> Sources (Select any directory and mark it as resources or anything else you want)

What is good practice?

It is possible to mark any directory as resources folder or put resource files in any Java package but this generally isn't encouraged. You should follow project/directory structure conventions. Usually resources folder is separated from the code. I have added link to some blogs, give them a read and understand project structure conventions.

Also note that there is no such thing as bot modules in Java.

Helpful blogs:

Maven standard directory structure

Read File from resources folder

Maven directory structure

I figured it out after checking some docs and with help from the community.

Coming from a Node.js background, I wasn’t used to how Java handles source roots. In Java, folders inside src/main/java are tied to package names, so IntelliJ expects you to create them as packages, not raw directories.

The fix:
Right-click → New → Package instead of New → Directory.
That way, IntelliJ links the folder to the correct package structure.

Thanks to everyone who helped clarify this!

question_comments.body: "Inside IntelliJ, the nested packages sometimes show as a single folder with dots" – This is a feature, not a bug. It's also only a visual thing. The com/discordbot/sentry directory structure is how the com.discordbot.sentry package is represented on the file system, and so the IDE displays it as a package, but it remains nested folders behind the scenes. Also, Java projects typically separate sources and resources. A "sources root" is explicitly and specifically for source files. Other resources go in the "resources root" (e.g., src/main/resources in Maven/Gradle based projects).

A source folder is for sources. You want to put resources directories that don't contain sources then you must change it to not sources. Also build systems like Maven and Gradle use different directories for resources and sources by convention. Is this enough explanation? Note that your question implies that you are asking for the reasoning, which may get opinion answers and not be a good question for Stack Overflow.
If it is a source folder the directory and file names within it must conform to the Java naming constraints. Normal directories and files must not. I guess that's the reason.
